conclusion: To solve the problem, the solution involves analyzing the image, identifying the shadows cast by the objects, and determining how these shadows will change when the light source moves to the front right, considering both position and size changes.

The image shows four objects on a tiled floor, each casting a distinct shadow on the ground. The shadows are labeled as A, B, C, and D, and the objects are positioned such that their shadows fall in different directions and areas on the floor.
The shadows A, B, C, and D on the floor correspond to the four objects above them.
The current position of the light source is on the left, causing the shadows to be cast to the right.
When the light source moves to the front right, it will no longer be perpendicular to the objects, and this change in angle will affect the shadows.
The shadows will elongate and become larger due to the angle change, as objects generally cast longer shadows when light hits them from a more direct angle.
The shadows will shift in position, moving towards the right as the light source moves rightward.
When the light source moves to the front right, the shadows A, B, C, and D will both increase in size and shift their positions on the ground.
The shadow of object A will move towards the right side of the slabs.
The shadow of object B will also move towards the right.
The shadow of object C will stretch and become longer.
The shadow of object D will shift towards the right and increase in size.
The exact changes in the shadows will depend on the angle at which the light source moves and its distance from the objects.
These changes in shadow size and position can be observed only when the light source is in motion.
